data.text: Credit risk is one of the supervisory priorities for 2021. Watch Supervisory Board member Elisabeth McCaul explain why banks’ credit risk is an important issue and what the pandemic has to do with it. Find out more about all our priorities https://t.co/wP33OKusFe https://t.co/a6IoQW7Fgn

Strong fiscal responses early in the pandemic were crucial in limiting economic damage in the euro area. The recovery needs support from targeted fiscal measures that consider the pandemic’s path and effectiveness of policy instruments. https://t.co/8lqPb6g23I  #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/5PArGrxVe8

The ECB responded very quickly to the deepest economic collapse in post-war times by ensuring favourable financing conditions, Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel told Deutschlandfunk. This was for the benefit of euro area citizens https://t.co/az7VimYpcG https://t.co/GXiWl7GyhG https://t.co/oVtdztharX

Non-commodity-related supply effects are a factor in price dynamics, and can be captured well by a granular analysis. This can help analyse how prices respond to the coronavirus crisis and could remain useful after it. Read more https://t.co/LM2TpH7qqZ #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/Wr84tdxz6N

Positive news about coronavirus vaccines led investors to return to financial assets previously hit by the pandemic. This benefitted economies that were lagging behind and led to an overall easing of financial conditions. Read more https://t.co/6ioqt0U4gL #EconomicBulletin

Fiscal and monetary policy have successfully stabilised the economy, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. This support should continue for as long as needed to prevent the virtuous circle between sovereigns, banks and firms from turning vicious https://t.co/QeVNUt9wFI https://t.co/eRUvB9xLuT
Today is Data Protection Day. President Christine Lagarde recorded a message to mark the occasion. Watch here https://t.co/wmYyd4M2EO
Euro area economic and financial developments by institutional sector (Q3 2020) https://t.co/JtTS5RMRXM
Occasional paper: The macroeconomic impact of the Next Generation EU instrument on the euro area https://t.co/fHPqtKTTEd
Working paper: Transforming ‘sympathetic interlocutors’ into veto players https://t.co/PY8OWYJR2R
Enria: We made a clear recommendation to exercise extreme moderation in remuneration in this extraordinary year.

Enria: The negative interest rate policy has a negative effect on interest rate margins, but a compensating effect on lending volumes and on market valuations. It has avoided an even harsher recession and a deterioration of asset quality.
Enria: I hope that there will be no need for asset management companies but it is important to make some preparations in this respect.
Enria: We will start soon with the SREP 2021 cycle but we will give time to the banks to rebuild the buffers, at least until end 2022.
Enria: We have intensified our pressure on banks on leveraged loans and we are asking for very attentive risk management in this area.
Enria: There is concern on business model sustainability and consolidation could be an avenue to address this concern.
Enria: On dividends, significant institutions are complying with our recommendations. Banks are giving positive feedback on their intention to comply.

Enria: The pandemic weighed on bank profitability compounding existing structural weaknesses. Still, in 2020 some banks started taking beneficial transformation actions. Learning from this will help tackle the profitability issue going forward.

Enria: Banks should act early to avoid cliff effects due to public support measures expiring. While credit risk increased within moratoria, credit impairments remain comparable to the broader loan book. We will closely monitor how banks identify and measure credit risk.

Enria: Banks’ provisions appear to fall below comparative levels which may be due to the unique features of this crisis. We expect that social restriction policies will demand additional efforts and we remain vigilant to banks’ practices leading to under-provisioning.

Enria: Credit risk and profitability are our main supervisory concerns. Increasing provisioning costs signal that banks are preparing for an increase in non-performing loans, but their preparations vary widely. Credit risk management remains one of our priorities.
Enria: We have so far avoided excessive procyclicality as lending to firms and households continued in 2020 and up to now, credit standards have tightened less than in past crises.

Enria: Credit losses from the pandemic are yet to materialise: buffer usage appears to be rather driven by individual structural issues than by the pandemic. Banks we supervise are well capitalised and we encourage them to use the ample room that is available to absorb losses.

Enria: European banks were resilient in 2020 when the pandemic shock hit. They have so far absorbed the shock rather than amplifying it. Prudential measures doubled banks’ capital headroom, enabling them to cope with the impact and continue lending to the economy.
Introductory statement by Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria to the ECB Banking Supervision Press Conference https://t.co/KVbdCW08fF
Tune in now to watch the ECB Banking Supervision press conference https://t.co/hZFpgzc9vo https://t.co/SB33JMwVZG

Our supervisory priorities for 2021:

➡️ credit risk management
➡️ capital strength
➡️ business model sustainability
➡️ governance

Watch Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria explain how we’ve identified them and what they mean. More on the priorities https://t.co/wP33OKusFe https://t.co/HxMr1vXhXu
➡️ On efficiency: Supervisors have been encouraging banks to overhaul their strategies and are closely monitoring the implementation of banks’ strategic actions to improve efficiency 3/3
➡️ On credit risk: Supervisors recommend banks to follow appropriately prudent approaches, as the risk of cliff effects may increase in 2021 due to the phasing-out of support measures 2/3

[Thread] The results of our 2020 supervisory review (SREP) are in: With vulnerabilities remaining, banks need to pay attention to credit risk and improve their efficiency 1/3
 
➡️ https://t.co/UP3GuoeAp8 (press release)
➡️ https://t.co/un6BbHejuH (Full SREP results)

The pandemic is an artificial type of recession, in that it is caused by the suspension of normal economic activity, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells Greece’s @skaigr. When that suspension is over, we expect to see a strong recovery. Full interview https://t.co/FTUXibVxxD https://t.co/Kjxl56Vrtn

Today is International Holocaust Remembrance Day. On this day, we light a candle to remember the 10,000 Jewish Frankfurters deported between 1941 and 1945 from the Großmarkthalle, which is now part of the ECB premises. May their memory be a blessing.

La finanza sostenibile è un’importante innovazione per porre il sistema finanziario al servizio del benessere collettivo, e richiede un coordinamento a livello globale, afferma il Membro del Comitato esecutivo Fabio Panetta.
Leggi l’intervento https://t.co/jfilCChYcb https://t.co/WgrB6srLLj

Tune in at 14:45 CET! Following his nomination as Supervisory Board Vice-Chair, Executive Board member @FrankElderson will speak before the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee of the @Europarl_EN. Follow the discussion https://t.co/5O2JDcLV9M @EP_Economics https://t.co/TDWSXBjA0i

Panetta: The ECB has to protect its balance sheet from the risks caused by climate change. By performing a rigorous analysis of these risks, the ECB can contribute to their accurate valuation.
Read the speech https://t.co/AzQSaPGxvv 5/5

Panetta: Sustainable development is among the objectives of the European Union. As such it is among the secondary aims of the ECB, which can contribute to environmental policies in the implementation of monetary policy, for example through sustainable finance instruments 4/5

Panetta: European regulation should ensure exhaustive information as to whether investments meet sustainability criteria. Empirical evidence indicates that disclosure makes firms pay more attention to sustainability without worsening their performance 3/5

Panetta: Sustainable investment projects can play a crucial role in helping to invest excess savings and raise the growth potential of the global economy, while also designing a growth path that reduces social vulnerabilities and counteracts climate risks 2/5

(THREAD) Sustainable finance represents an important innovation designed to ensure that the financial system is used for our collective well-being. It requires global coordination, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta 1/5 https://t.co/4L2vZ6EcrY

Climate change is becoming more important for the economy and the ECB’s policy. That’s why we will open a climate change centre. The centre will strengthen and bring together our work on climate change and sustainable finance https://t.co/hXY95MZFP2 https://t.co/Bb3p3Gfqy0

We will use our own funds to invest in the green bond fund set up by @BIS_org. This way we contribute to the global efforts to combat climate change. The fund provides capital for renewable energy production, energy efficiency and other green projects https://t.co/hLi1nLzOtH https://t.co/qLwWoFXWSL

We need a consistent framework for managing crises of smaller banks, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. Key ingredients are a European deposit insurance scheme, regulatory harmonisation, and European tools for the liquidation of banks of all sizes https://t.co/ITyasuroxD https://t.co/DuznVS3Rmk

What is a #digitaleuro? It would be an electronic form of central bank money accessible to all citizens and firms – like banknotes, but in a digital form – to make your daily payments in a fast, easy and secure way. Find out more https://t.co/RiwOCers68

Thank you to everyone who participated in our public consultation on a #digitaleuro. We will now analyse the 8,221 responses and publish a detailed analysis in the spring. This will help us decide whether to launch a digital euro project https://t.co/rPBASeybxu https://t.co/KXvQZkowN1

Tax effects and rising energy prices are expected to put some upward pressure on inflation in 2021, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. But projected inflation remains distant from our aim in the medium term, which is what matters for our monetary policy. https://t.co/MFmekjgpZk

The ECB will use its supervisory tools to facilitate sustainable consolidation among banks. We encourage them to engage with supervisors early on and explain our expectations in a guide, which also benefited from banks’ input. Read the full guide https://t.co/OJkbCLegJI https://t.co/PcxjeOFO23
